Recent studies have demonstrated the potential of bats to act as reservoirs of zoonotic pathogens (reviewed in
1 ). One example is the common and conspicuous straw-coloured fruit bat ( Eidolon helvum), which has been identified as a reservoir host for Lagos bat virus (LBV, family Rhabdoviridae, genus Lyssavirus)
2 and henipaviruses (family Paramyxoviridae)
3 in mainland Africa. E. helvum is a gregarious, predominantly tree-roosting species and large roosts (sometimes numbering more than one million bats) frequently exist in close proximity to large human settlements, including Accra (Ghana), Abidjan (Côte d’Ivoire), Dar es Salaam (Tanzania), Lagos (Nigeria), and Kampala (Uganda)
4 .
